wesm commented on issue #4598: ARROW-5635: [C++] Added a Compact() method to Table.
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4598#issuecomment-504064747
 
 
   @brills what is the expected behavior if `Compact` is invoked on a Table having a column with binary type, where concatenation is not possible (due to exceeding the 2GB memory limit)?
   
   I also agree we might call this `CombineChunks` or similar
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

users@infra.apache.org

brills commented on issue #4598: ARROW-5635: [C++] Added a Compact() method to Table.
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4598#issuecomment-504120539
 
 
   Re: naming:
   "Compact" comes from the very old bigtable paper [1] where they do similar things by combining shards into one. I'm fine with CombineChunks and made the change.
   
   Re: 2GB memory limit for BinaryArrays:
   I'm not super familiar with the codebase, but it seems this memory limit is only enforced by the Builder [2], and Concatenate() works directly with Buffers so it will still be able to make a buffer larger than 2GB. I guess I can do a separate PR to make Concatenate() check for the size?
   
   On the other hand, it seems not ideal if the combining is prevented by some columns. Maybe I should also add Column::CombineChunks? I assume Columns in a Table don't have to have the same layout.
   
   [1] https://static.googleusercontent.com/media/research.google.com/en//archive/bigtable-osdi06.pdf (section 5.4)
   [2] https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/cdedd85f9c8545ab3c98e7b9de938a28d1ec9e11/cpp/src/arrow/array/builder_binary.h#L35
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

fields.description: A column in a table might consists of multiple chunks. I'm proposing a Table.Compact() method that returns a table whose columns are of just one chunks, which is the concatenation of the corresponding column's chunks.
